rsbNotes.title: Ps 120
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 120 This psalm is the first of the fifteen “Songs of Ascents” (120–134). As tradition suggests, they were sung by pilgrims traveling to the mountain of God (Zion) to worship. Ps. 120 opens the group appropriately with the song of a faithful worshiper who is far away from the temple among pagan people (v. 5 note).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 120:2
rsbNotes.text: 120:2 lying lips . . . deceitful tongue. The psalmist’s enemies slander him unmercifully.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 120:3
rsbNotes.text: 120:3 to you. The enemy whose lies trouble the psalmist.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 120:4
rsbNotes.text: 120:4 warrior’s sharp arrows. The liars will be repaid in kind.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 120:5
rsbNotes.text: 120:5 Meshech . . . Kedar. The writer may be speaking figuratively, comparing the treatment he receives from God’s people to what he might expect from barbarians. The literal places are far from Israel and also from each other. Meshech was in Asia Minor (Gen. 10:2; Ezek. 38:2) and Kedar was in Arabia (Is. 21:16; Ezek. 7:21).
